mobile.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Give me a call on my mobile.
Have you got my mobile number?
mobile.translation[0].definitions[1].def: a decoration made of small objects tied to wires or string which is hung up so that the objects move when air blows around them
mobile.translation[1].definitions[0].def: not fixed in one position, and easy to move and use in different places
mobile.translation[1].definitions[1].def: moving or able to move from one job, area, or social class to another
mobile.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: People these days are much more socially mobile.
an upwardly mobile  (=moving to a higher social scale) professional
mobile.translation[1].definitions[2].def: able to move or travel easily
mobile.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: She’s more mobile now that she has her own car.
mobile.translation[1].note_box[0].headin: – Meaning 2: moving or able to move from one job, area, or social class to another
mobile.translation[1].note_box[0].sectio: We now live in a highly mobile society.
The restaurant's customers are mainly upwardly mobile young professionals.
Children today are even less likely to be socially mobile.
mobile.translation[2].definitions[0].def: a city which is Alabama's only port and one of the busiest ports in the US
mobile.translation[3].definitions[0].def: a small phone that you can carry with you
mobile.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: Phone companies are trying to make the fraudulent use of stolen mobiles more difficult.
